topics.title: Introduction and Overview
topics.description: The host introduces himself and his expertise in building drones. He explains that this video will cover the process of building a drone from scratch.
topics.coverage_text:
So, I finally did it. After stating in a video from 2017 that I would finish a DIY drone by 2022,
I am happy to say that I was finally able to put together this drone. Which can in fact fly but
I am still a beginner when it comes to controlling it. Now you probably already noticed that this is
not your standard drone like for example DJI mostly makes them which fly rather slow and controlled
so that you can make beautiful recordings. No, this is an FPV or first person view drone meaning
you can not only see what the drone sees while flying but it also moves way faster through the

topics.title: Designing the Drone
topics.description: The host discusses his design decisions and how he created the drone's body. He also explains why certain components were chosen.
topics.coverage_text:
air and thus lets you capture some unique video footage with the help of a GoPro on top.
And the reason why I built this was that months ago I got a beginners FPV drone kit that came with a tiny
drone which works wonderfully but can easily get blown away by the wind. So, I wanted something a
bit bigger and heavier and I feel like I went overboard here but you will see that later.
Before that though let me show you my journey of building this thing which was not super easy to
do because the drone market just overflows with different hardware, communication protocols and
software. But luckily after this video you should have a good idea of what is going on and you should

topics.title: Building the Frame
topics.description: The host talks about building the frame of the drone using 3D printed parts. He explains how he modified some of the parts to fit his design.
topics.coverage_text:
be able to build something similar. So, let's get started!
This video is sponsored by Keysight who have a huge virtual event coming up called Keysight World Innovate.
It is 4 days long and during that time industry leaders and experts will share their vision of future
technology which involves 5G and 6G, electric and autonomous vehicle advances, quantum technology
and much much more. If that sounds interesting to you then check out the link in the video description.
Let's start off by exploring what parts we need for drone and let's use my completed one as an example.
The first obvious part is of course a frame onto which all other components get mounted on.
Next are the motors with propellers that create the upward thrust while spinning and of course we also

topics.title: Assembling the Drone
topics.description: The host walks viewers through the process of assembling the drone's components. He explains how he connected the frame to the flight controller and motor.
topics.coverage_text:
need a battery to power it all. Then some kind of receiver that like the name implies receives a signal
from a remote so that the drone knows what direction to follow. And since we are dealing with an FPV drone,
we also need a camera and a VTX system with fitting antenna of which I honestly also never heard of before.
It stands for Video Transmitter and it basically takes the camera video signal and sends it out as
a 5.8GHz signal that the FPV goggles which we also need can then receive and play back.
And the last things they are missing are the VC board and ESC board.
Now FC stands for Flight Controller and it is basically the heart of the system.
It for example comes with an accelerometer IC which the drone uses to find out how it is positioned in
the air and through the help of an integrated PID control loop it can then tell each motor how fast
to spin so that it can stand upright in the air without crashing. Of course it also manages to receive

topics.title: Configuring Betaflight
topics.description: The host explains how he configured the drone's flight settings using the Betaflight software. He talks about calibrating the accelerometer and setting up modes.
topics.coverage_text:
controller signal, camera signal, outputs the VTX signal and much much more.
The only big thing it cannot do directly is driving the BLDC motors for which we got the ESC board
aka electronic speed controller board that drives the motors at a specific speed depending on how the
flight controller demands it. And those were all in all the basic components required for an FPV drone
and I started my component hunt by firstly looking for a frame. The reason is that depending on whether
you choose a small or big frame all the other components have to be smaller or bigger too.
And honestly speaking I didn't feel like buying a pre-made frame because when 3D printing a frame
you can always easily replace parts and by using PETG filament you also get reasonably strong parts
which eventually though can also break. So I searched for suitable models on printables
and eventually found this 6 inch one whose design I really liked. I asked his creator whether I can

topics.title: First Flight Tests
topics.description: The host shares his experiences with the first few flights of his drone. He discusses the challenges he faced and what he learned from the experience.
topics.coverage_text:
showcase it in the video and he agreed and even helped me a lot during the build so big thanks to him.
And with the model selected I started 3D printing all parts
and while that was going on I was looking for motors on Amazon which the model trader actually advised me
not to use. The reason is that they often come with low quality bearings so he instead recommended this
motor in combination with a 4S battery. With the given kV rating using a 4S battery should give me an
average RPM of 37,814 which is above the RPM thrust graph I created in a previous video and thus it should
easily lift 500g meaning 4 of them should be able to do 2kg which I thought was more than enough.
And by the way I would highly recommend checking out the video I just mentioned because it shows you
very well how battery, ESC, motor and propeller interplay with one another.
But anyway the datasheet of the motor also stated that even with only 50% thrust it is capable of

topics.title: Conclusion
topics.description: The host wraps up the video by summarizing the key takeaways and sharing his thoughts on building a drone. He encourages viewers to share their own experiences in the comments.
topics.coverage_text:
lifting 563g so I was pretty sure that those should work. Next for the propellers I was advised to get 6 inch
ones but once I saw how close they get to the drone maybe turning it into drone goulash I instead went with generic 5 inch ones.
For the battery like I said before I went with a 4S one with a capacity of 2.2Ah and most importantly a
high C rating which basically says that it can output a high current and thus a high power which is more than
enough to enjoy the maximum power of all 4 motors. Moving on, next was the receiver and remote part
and for that I wanted to reuse the remote from my beginners drone kit. Luckily it apparently comes
with the ELRS communication protocol that can be used for modern drones. As a comparison back in the old
days all your drone remote inputs would alter one data channel at the receiver which is basically a standard
servo signal. But since dealing with so many data channels is just confusing, modern remotes and
receivers just talk to the flight controller through a receive and transmit line and thus we reduced for
